description: From Old English bannuc, from Old Irish bannach, based on Latin pānicum (“millet”). Doublet of bonnag.

entries.meaning: (especially Scotland, Northern England) An unleavened bread made with barley, wheat, or oatmeal.
examples: So she baked two oatmeal bannocks, and set them on to the fire to harden. After a while, the old man came in, and sat down beside the fire, and takes one of the bannocks, and snaps it through the middle.

entries.meaning: (Canada) A biscuit bread made of wheat flour or cornmeal, fat, and sometimes baking powder, typically baked over a fire, wrapped around a stick or in a pan.
